title: Fagg, Robinson failures rewarded by NAB, Incitec Pivot
text:
Any illusion of nascent meritocracy in the boardrooms of corporate Australia was nipped in the bud on Tuesday when a game of musical chairs broke out in a cosy corner of the Melbourne Club (or was it the Qantas Chairman’s Lounge?).

At Incitec Pivot, Kathryn Fagg signalled her intention to quit as a director after five years, having secured a spot on the more prestigious board of National Australia Bank. Naturally! The NAB even topped the biography with her induction into the Order of Australia this year, a ludicrous non-qualification with which to lead a director’s profile.

Incitec announced Fagg’s place would be taken by former Newcrest Mining chief executive Greg Robinson. Having covered the last joint in shit, Robinson’s the ideal director for a fertiliser producer.

Over his three years running Newcrest (July 2011 to July 2014), total shareholder returns were negative 70 per cent. And in a settlement with the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, the gold miner agreed to pay a record $1.2 million fine for selectively briefing the market in 2013.

As for Fagg, one might’ve imagined she’d have her hands full as chairman of Boral, a job she took on in July last year (having been a director since 2014). The board let CEO Mike Kane pay $US2.6 billion (then $3.5 billion) for Utah building products group Headwaters in May 2017. Boral’s TSR since then? Negative 15.8 per cent. Inexplicably in light of the company’s lacklustre performance, in March Fagg allowed Kane to distract himself with a side hustle and join the board of Sims Metal. Management oversight doesn’t get much feebler.

On goes the time-honoured principle of Australian business: FUMU. F--- up, move up.
description: The time-honoured principle of getting on in Australian business continues.
